139223492.review:
This game is based on frontlines. 
The player does not plop units in provinces, but creates sections at the enemy border, and assigns AI lead armies of around 24 divisions which in turn attack or defend, in accordance to the player's instructions. 
Well, the front-line mechanics are a mess. Attacking from multiple directions and/or axii is a recipe for trouble, for example Germany attacking Poland from both East Prussia and Brandenburg. The fronts get tangled up upon joining from multiple axii of advance as if a cat ran headfirst into a Christmas tree, got stuck, struggled as if about to die and was meshed in all the needles and tinsel, then ran away and took the entire f--kin' thing down as it went. The frontlines were supposed to help the player evade needless microing, but it turns out the only way to ensure nothing stupid happens is to babysit the damned AI. 

Some of the worst border, or in this case Front-Gore I've seen in a Paradox game is from frontlines getting messed up, multiple nations getting pockets of units all over the place, as well as the AI at times stretching an army of 24 divisions aaall the way through the entire Soviet Eastern front, and just having the divisions stand in place, or aimlessly reassigning them in reaction to other armies capturing territory. The AI is bad overall and the Frontline UI is pretty terrible. There are keybinds and hot buttons galore, and playing with them feels like entering a cheat code to a retro game from the 90s. How is it this complicated and awkward to order simple pincer move? Which the AI will likely mess up, anyway. 

Supply mechanics are atrocious, and the game does not know what information to share with the player. 
For example, I just had game as Germany invading Norway around Early '39. A single army of some marines, mountaineers and infantry, with air support. Far superior to the defenders, I'd add. The issue is, that the player has no idea what is causing the army to lose so much gear. 
It's actually infuriating. That single army seems to go through tens of thousands of units of Infantry Equipment just marching in Norway, and having the occasional battle with far smaller Norwegian defenders. How much equipment are they using, and why? I dunno. The game doesn't tell me. I just eyeball the supply strength bar and scratch my head. 
What am I losing that equipment to? Enemy activity? Attrition? Angry Norweigian Mööse attacking at night, stealing the Gerries' bang-bangs to sell to biker gangs?
Some of those divisions have done nothing but stand in mountainous provinces for a few in game weeks, and are at 60% equipment strength. I'm guessing this is due to logistics getting stretched, but come on-- The game does not tell me that. So, in turn the player does not know how to amend the situation. The roads seem fine, the rail network isn't off, and my side has the air superiority, as well secure naval routes with a high level ports close-by. 
Talk to me, tell me, game! This is not Victoria 2 where one just stumbles across a solution to a problem sifting through spread sheets, and having an A-ha! - moment, but more like the Atari E.T. falling into a poorly hit boxed pit and floating out tens of times each minute. It feels like I'm fighting the game mechanics, and not the enemy forces. It's frustrating. 

Then there's combat, and naval invasions which tie into both issues. 
It's annoying how combat has only one speed and intensity. One is either attacking, defending or passive. There's no scouting or skirmishing, just full on First Day of Somme all the time. This means armies on broad fronts can attack, and go through massive amounts of stacked equipment in a matter of days. And of course the player isn't told what is causing those losses. Enemy air power? Tanks pounding the front? Artillery? Infantry waves? Armies can be full green, about to win a battle at 90% progress, and still hemorrhage tanks and infantry equipment to the point of any large offence being a Pyrrhic affair at best. 
The commander AI is bad, and has a tendency to either play self-destructively aggressive, or move the divisions into an optimal place before an assault, and do this slowly enough that front shifts before being finished, after which the AI is likely to do this again, and again. 
The battles proper are simplistic, with rather crude modifiers for attack, defense, breakthrough and armor piercing affecting combat rounds. This is often moot, as the side with the better supply will usually win. Generals pick doctrine modifiers from a list of unlocked tactics, which are rather underwhelming. The tactics used in a battle do not affect the larger operations much, if at all. 
A victory in a single province does not affect the other active combats in any way. E.g. crushing the enemy in one province does not cause organization damage of any sort in the neighboring province, unless attacking from the newly opened avenue. The speed is either stuck at Verdun, or the breakneck brutality of the invasion of Poland. 
Naval invasions are poorly implemented. One *has* to supply an invasion through a port, and there is no way to create an Overlord type of beachhead at a suitable location, and move inland from there. Coasts cannot be raided and probed for a weak point and maybe grabbing a poorly defended island or a base. Maybe a beachhead could be established over the weeks, and the defender would have to rush in order to smash the fledgling landing. Instead, one has to capture an existing port, and once landed an army cannot retreat unless via port. There are no Dunkirk saves in HoI4. 
Naval invasions are awkward, and take very long in-game to plan and execute. 

It just makes cheesing the AI the only solid way to win consistently. Knowing the game isn't understanding the supply or the tactics, but seeing exploits all over and using them. This is not to evade enemy power, as is, but to make sure one doesn't get tangled in the bad frontline mechanics and supply system. 

And these issues either haven't been fixed over the years, or more problems have appeared with expansions. It's not the worst game ever, but do I recommend investing hundreds of hours to it? No. Hearts of Iron 4 is some messy and wonky Grand Strategy. Try this one on discount, get the DLC subscription and see if it tickles you. It's more like an occasional slight rash i get, and I subscribe to the game thinking 'Why'd I stop playing before?' and play a campaign for a while and it call comes rolling back, like a very persistent case of slight winter dandruff.

134616620.review:
Beneath the surface, Hearts of Iron has a solid core, and perhaps the best battle system out of any of their games so far. While not as in-depth as its predecessor yet, this game has a very good foundation that if used in the right way could make it better than the rest. However, sadly it seems this game suffers from a multitude of problems that plague other Paradox games, as well as very limiting design features. Instead of being a comprehensive list, I’ll just name the ones that stand out the most to me:  

- [b]Repetitive gameplay; hard to approach systems.[/b] This game relies on focus trees for most of its main decisions, which are a system which is inherently limiting and repetitive. For a game that prides itself on going a different way in history, there isn’t much in the way of choice (let alone nuance) besides just “democratic” or broad big-tent fascism, communism, or the occasional monarchist/non-aligned. Besides that there is the industry with more in-depth systems for tanks or your navy you can play around with, but those systems are often the other way; far too complex and hard to approach, with no little in the way of tutorials to teach them. This leads to most players just flat out giving up on those rather large portions of the game, which leaves the often long waiting period till war very tedious, and inevitably little in the way of reward. 
- [b]The lack of content without and outside of DLCs.[/b] I know we still get some free updates, but much of the base game is still almost [i]criminally[/i] undeveloped without any expansion packs, or nothing if you’re a country outside of the scope of any content updates. Then even still if you own a few DLCs, good luck if they have any outdated focus trees or reworks in them, because it’s a rarity for them to come back and fix stuff; especially without making a whole new DLC on top of another. Don’t get me wrong, some of the stuff they've done with supply (No Step Back) and intelligence agencies (La Résistance) are fantastic, but come on, we did pay for a whole game here. 
- [b]The lack of actual simulation of a state, and especially more so the lack of representation of historical atrocities like the Holocaust.[/b] While I know this can’t be Victoria level state-management (though that would be nice) there needs to be a level of internal workings simulated outside of the occasional event, and even more so for the ideology you go with. As it stands, outside what tree you go down it’s really an aesthetic choice that fails to show the workings and weight which that choice would entail, or even the people’s opinion during the time. And with that second thing, it’s no secret that Paradox tends to shy away or even whitewash topics like genocide that takes place in their games, but at the [i]very least[/i] they cannot be neutral on perhaps the most political war in history. In my opinion these are the main reasons why this game’s community tends to be questionable at best, with one of the worst pipelines to fascism (or at the very least romanization) out there. 

The [i]only[/i] reason I would recommend this game is the community mods, as it seems similar to Bethesda they wish more for modders to provide what they will not. Road to 56, Old World Blues, The New Order: Last Days of Europe or Thousand Week Reich, Red Flood, and of course Kiaserreich/Kiaserredux are all great examples of community made mods, that while they do have their own problems, they still surpass the game that they used as a base. Still though, I genuinely would not recommend the base game for even $20, let alone the asking $50 (CAD). But if you like history, and can pick it up for less than $10, I’d actually recommend it.  

[spoiler]Sorry no comments this time around, but I know better than to leave them on here [/spoiler]

It's a WWII game, there's only so much diplomacy, and the game gets stale pretty fast if you only play historical AI. 

Meanwhile, onto nonhistorical AI. The game basically introduced far too many interactions and events without questioning whether the underlying logic makes sense. 

In my last game as Germany, I immediately justified and declared on Poland, then the Soviets. Again, nonhistorical to spice things up. As a WWII oriented game, obviously the German-Soviet war should be heavily focused on during development. 

In reality, during my war with the Soviets, they first called in the Czechs, even though they weren't in the same faction and the Czechs weren't communist. Makes total sense, the Soviets are under attack, of course Czechoslovakia would be willing to get crushed to save the Soviets. I deploy troops, and crush the Czechs. But before they capitulated, Austria formed Austria-Hungary and absorbed all of Czechoslovakia. I lose all the land I captured, and am not at war with Austria. Yep, that's totally how Germany would have reacted. I continue pushing against the Soviets, and two Soviet civil wars erupt back-to-back, which were both quenched within a day without any cities being taken. Meanwhile, I lose land that I controlled and some of my troops got encircled. And this called in Sinkiang and Communist China into the war. Big brain move, why didn't people do this during WWII IRL? Would have taken Berlin in a month. Whatever. Then a third soviet civil war erupted, and this time since Japan was at war with communist China, all of the soviets was taken by Japan. Ok, wow. So yeah, millions of lives lost, land conquered, guns fired, and I get, nothing. My war score tanked. Obviously I was at 100% before, but now, without any units stepping on Soviet land or fighting any Soviet troops, the Japanese got 70% war score, and since I can't do anything to finish the rest of the war with China, the Japanese war score is just going to keep rising. 

This does not make sense. I don't care if the devs decide to rework all those minor nations. I care that the rest of the game does not get affected. I just want to be able to go to war without every other nation be like, hmmm, legally you are not allowed to fight anymore. 

Don't bother buying anything past Man the Guns. I honestly might just disable every DLC since that. The later DLCs just make the game worse.

I've played this game for almost 1000 hours now and I've come to realize i actually kind of wasted every hour of that.
Don't get me wrong here, hoi4 is a good game, in that with sufficient friends and imagination you can have some very good times in this game. The large library of mods make you play every scenario, but in my onion the cons often outweigh the pros.

To give a few examples; the game and especially the launcher are laggy at best and crash when you click some random buttons. Also there is an enormous learning curve of this game. Not that that is necessarily a bad thing, wanting to learn something new is good but if I look at myself and my friends, you need to put a good 50 hours in to get the basics of everything ( focus tree effects, creating division templates, government management etc) and add in an extra 100 to get good at it. Having to spend 50 days (say you play 3 hours, everyday) just getting good at a game in my opinion, is a waste of time. Oh and forgot to mention top players have like 2000 hours so good luck with that.

If, and only if you really like strategy games from paradox, never played real strategy games this is a good test to see if you can withstand the huge grind it is to get good at it. If that's the case, well have at it. on a good sale it's like 10-20 bucks and mods are free. Otherwise I wouldn't recommend. After playing a game you've played at least 2 hours which means you can't even return it because it was not to your liking.

I understand this game is meant to be dense and detailed, but this is Microsoft Flight Simulator levels of "We explain little, and what we don't explain will kill you, good luck". I'm a casual gamer, who has played numerous other Paradox titles, but this one has absolutely soured me on the entire franchise.

136428885.review:
Whilst Hoi4 was a fun game, it's unplayable without mods or dlc. Most mods require all of the DLC or at least the first couple. I've put many hours and a lot of money into this game. I enjoy it loads, but i don't feel it was worth the money, especially with how lazy the devs are getting with the newest DLCs. (I dont blame the devs themselves, i blame the higher-ups pushing them to release subpar content for a deadline rather than actually letting them flesh out each dlc. 

My recommendation is for the people that already own the game and want to buy all the DLC, get them on sale btw. I can't recommend the game to new players who dont own the game or have never played it. 

i have limited experience in multiplayer but it's given me enough insight to say that everyone involved must have super fast connection and god help you if youre playing in different regions. The long 70-day focuses and awful meta game (7-2s and 14-4s are all you see out of randoms) make both diplomacy and wars slow and grindy. in single player you either get rolled by ai or completely curb-stomp them. The balance is completely dead. Make 7-2s, get a half decent tank division, build fighters and cas, and you win the game. 

There exists elements of a strategy game but hardly any implementation. Terrain bonuses either do nothing to affect your decision making or become the sole focus of it. For example, as Italy you would want to defend mountains and hills, this would practically halt any ai army and slow down players significantly. As the USSR you never make a decision like "Hm i should concentrate more troops in the plains than in the marshes because the plains are harder to defend". Whether a tile is a mountain or not is the only terrain-related decision that ever matters in the grand scheme of things. There is a poor diversity of infantry units. The player can only make generic Infantry, no jungle, desert, forest, etc Infantry. You can make mountaineers but they count towards your special forces cap instead of being a regular infantry type. Speaking of special forces; paratroopers are useless and only serve as a way to waste manpower and take up precious room for your marines. If you have the air superiority to drop paratroopers its much more effective and efficient to simply use cas or strat bombers to soften up the frontline.

138871334.review:
Vanilla game, no mods, personal record before game gets corrupted save and permanent CTD state: 1940.

But let's say that you don't have this issue for some reason.  Let's say that it works for you.  Great.  Hope you've got a spare $1000 laying around to play the entire game.  Even Paradox knows their DLC policy is total klept and has started offering subscriptions as an alternative.  That's right, subscriptions for a single-player game.  That's what it has come to.

And out of all these DLC, what are the ones that matter?  The ones that let design you own ships, tanks and aircraft of course.  Plural.  Because whilst all these things could have been easily combined into a single DLC that players would actually want and be useful, instead Paradox decided to split all these functions across three different DLCs, thus forcing you to buy all three of them if you want 100% functionality of what is, in essence, a single new feature.  All working as planned.

If you [i]do[/i] use mods then Ye Gods help you, because [i]every[/i] little patch - and they're almost weekly - will break them all.  Even if it's just a text correction of some typos, somehow it will explode every mod you have.  It's actually impressive, as I thought only Bannerlord was able to do this until now.  Yet as I said at the start, even playing a stock vanilla game I've found it to be as stable as a jar of nitroglycerin on a roller coaster.

And despite all of these constant expansions and add-ons, most of these new systems either don't work right, are horribly inbalanced, incomplete or unrealistic.  Why do cavalry need trucks to use the recon unit attachment?  Isn't the whole point of a horse unit that it doesn't need gasoline?  Why is every air wing in every country exactly 100 planes?  Do you know how many nations use 100 as the number of aircraft in a wing in the real world?  None.  Ever.  Are you seriously telling me that entire OSS conssists of three agents?  Rubber is a critical resource but food isn't?  Because I can assure you that starvation was a factor in many a real-world battle in Russia and the Pacific.  Air attacks against naval assets give precise casualty numbers but against ground targets becomes abstracted to the point where the info isn't even accessible.  Single naval battles don't last hours but rather a week or longer.

If can forgive a lot of funky mechanics in a game like Stellaris because it's science fiction.  HOI, however, is supposed to be based on reality so I'm holding it to a higher standard - and it is failing.  Between the endless bugs, the DLC avalanche and the overall bad design decisions this game is just not something that I can suggest anyone try to get into or further invest in.

144725565.review:
800 Hours and Counting!

Hearts of Iron IV is not just a game; it's an epic journey through the annals of history. With over 800 hours invested, I can confidently say that Hearts of Iron IV is a masterpiece of grand strategy that has captivated my gaming heart like no other.

From the moment I launched my first campaign in Hearts of Iron IV, I was transported into the turbulent era of World War II. The level of detail and historical accuracy in this game is nothing short of astounding. Every nation feels unique, with its own strengths, weaknesses, and historical focus. Whether I'm leading the Allies to victory, spearheading the Axis war machine, or steering a minor nation towards world domination, Hearts of Iron IV offers an unparalleled level of immersion.

One of the standout features of this game is the meticulous attention to historical events and the flexibility it offers in altering the course of history. The focus trees for major nations and the extensive modding community ensure that every playthrough is a fresh and engaging experience. Want to see what happens when Germany allies with the Soviet Union against the Allies? Go ahead and rewrite history. The possibilities are endless, and every decision you make has far-reaching consequences.

The sheer scale of the game is mind-boggling. Managing your nation's military, industry, diplomacy, and politics is a complex yet highly rewarding task. The planning and execution of military operations are where Hearts of Iron IV truly shines. The battle plans, troop movements, and strategic decisions you make can turn the tide of a war. The feeling of orchestrating a successful encirclement or pulling off a daring naval invasion is unparalleled in the world of strategy gaming.

The graphics and presentation are top-notch, with an attention to detail that brings the World War II era to life. The map is beautifully rendered, and watching the borders shift as wars rage on is a visual treat. The sound design, from the thunderous roar of artillery to the patriotic music of each nation, adds another layer of immersion.

Multiplayer is where Hearts of Iron IV truly comes alive. Coordinating with friends or competing against other players in epic multiplayer battles is an experience like no other. The alliances, betrayals, and diplomatic negotiations that unfold in multiplayer matches make for memorable gaming moments that keep me coming back for more.

Paradox Interactive's commitment to ongoing development and improvement is commendable. The regular updates and expansions add new layers of depth to an already complex game, ensuring that there is always something new to discover.

In conclusion, Hearts of Iron IV is a triumph of grand strategy gaming. With its historical accuracy, immersive gameplay, and endless replayability, it has consumed 800 hours of my life and counting. If you have even a passing interest in World War II or grand strategy games, Hearts of Iron IV is a must-play. It's not just a game; it's an epic historical journey that will keep you hooked for hundreds of hours. Thank you, Paradox Interactive, for creating this gaming masterpiece!
(however the dlcs are very expensive and the game is ass without them)

129107311.review:
A fantastic game without mods
A masterpiece with mods

Aspects of the game:
Combat: 9/10 (-1 for naval combat)
Production: 9/10
Building: 9/10 (-1 for tediousness)
Research: 10/10
Supply management: 9/10
Politics: 6/10
Unit design: 7/10 (fun but a bit tedious)
Economy: Na (more of a production game)

Although this game is extremely complex, you don't need to know every single thing to get into the game. 
There are some components that you need to know right off the bat (I highly recommend watching a 20 minute YouTube video to go over that).
After that though you can take on the more complicated aspects of the game at your own pace (I just built infantry+ artillery my first run as a small county)
Even with ~400 hours of enjoyment I've come to realize that I still haven't gotten into the depths of HOI4 (like specific stats, very specific army compositions for certain situations, resource availability, etc.).
Difficulty settings in the game are somewhat arbitrary because what really matters is what country you are playing. Playing Poland on easy settings is harder than playing Canada on hard settings for example. 

Don't buy ANY of the DLCs; many of the bigger mods have more (and better) content that all of the DLCs combined.

147318004.review: Despite my high playtime and the amount of fun times I've had throughout the years, I just don't think I can recommend this game in its current state. While there are a lot of cool features and it can be very fun at times, and even outside of the more interesting parts it can be relaxing to sit and build up your country while watching world events, there are many fundamental problems that have only been getting worse. For one, the DLC system has made the price to get all of the content increasingly unreasonable (I believe it is approaching 200 dollars at this point) and the devs seem to be more focused on adding more DLC/updates than fixing and integrating previous content with the new or optimizing the game, which has led to increasingly poor performance and many older features starting to break. With the worsening performance, it can take up to 10 hours to play a full game even with a decent CPU, and personally I don't think the enjoyment wrought from a game is enough to warrant playing for that long. There have been many a time where I played a game for 8 hours and eventually met all of my goals, but still walked away feeling like I had wasted half a day and sacrificed a good nights sleep so I could stare at a map instead of doing something actually fun or productive. Another matter, although one the devs have limited control over in all fairness, is the community. While most of the core community, such as those on offical forums and the communities based around larger content creators, are mostly just normal people trying to enjoy a strategy game, you will quickly run into neonazis, tankies, and other extremist nutjobs if you stray from this core, or look a little too closely into the corners of even the aformentioned normal spaces. While this is somewhat of an inevitability with any WW2 game, it seems like there is a higher concentration here, and I swear I've been finding them more and more in previously sane parts of the community. Between the DLC policy, the dropoff in enjoyment (especially considering the timesink it has become, which has negatively impacted my day-to-day life at points), and the increasingly toxic community, I have personally decided to stop playing this game for the time being. If you are looking for a strategy game, you might have some fun if you have a good computer, a few hundred bucks to shell out for the DLC (while technically optional, many a core feature is only avaliable with it), and dont mind having some of your friends look at you questionably while you desperately try to explain you aren't "one of those" hoi4 players, but otherwise I would advise against playing this game unless they iron some of the current issues out.

144592251.review:
Hearts of Iron IV... where do I even begin? This game is a rollercoaster of frustration and exasperation, a true exercise in patience and endurance. Yet, somehow, against all odds, I can't help but find myself drawn to its infuriating charm.

Let's start with the positives, shall we? The level of detail in Hearts of Iron IV is mind-boggling, I'll give it that. Paradox Interactive must have a team of historians locked away somewhere, meticulously recreating the events of World War II down to the tiniest of units. The sheer scope of strategic options available is overwhelming, and it's a credit to the game's designers that they've managed to cram so much complexity into the interface.

However, complexity doesn't always equate to fun. Hearts of Iron IV often feels like a never-ending struggle against its own mechanics. The micromanagement required to keep your sprawling empire in check is enough to give anyone a headache. I swear, I spend more time fumbling through menus and assigning tasks to divisions than actually enjoying the strategic aspect of the game. And don't even get me started on the AI. It's as if the developers thought, "Why let players have fun when we can have them fight against an AI that's simultaneously omniscient and utterly clueless?"

The graphics? Well, let's just say they won't be winning any awards anytime soon. I get it, this isn't a AAA title, but it's 2023, and the graphics in Hearts of Iron IV look like they were pulled from a history textbook. And don't even think about zooming in too close – the pixelated mess that greets you is an eyesore of monumental proportions.

But for all my complaints, here's the twist: I keep coming back to it. There's a certain perverse satisfaction that comes from outsmarting the broken AI, from somehow managing to keep your country afloat despite the barrage of bugs and quirks. Hearts of Iron IV is the kind of game that makes you feel like a tactical genius when things go right, even if they often go right for all the wrong reasons.

So, would I recommend Hearts of Iron IV? Well, it's a game that defies logic. It's clunky, it's infuriating, and it's undoubtedly one of the most complex strategy games out there. But if you're willing to wade through the muck and mire, there's a twisted kind of satisfaction to be found. Just be prepared to curse more than you'll care to admit.

There is a lot to like about the game, but the game is horribly difficult to learn.  The tutorial is inadequate and I have spent countless hours watching Youtube videos.  The UI for the game needs a complete overhaul.  Basically you are presented with dozens of buttons as opposed to walking you step by step through an attack plan.  The current orders for units are not tracked in a list, so you are often confused by what your units are trying to do.  Naval invasion plan had me select units even though I already had them selected.

I am only playing the base game, but I think this game is suffering from bloat creep.  This is the 4th version of the game I assume based on the name, however there are too many complicated systems to learn.  Simplifying systems is needed to make the game accessible.  In battles, I struggle to understand what is going on.  Where do I have air superiority, and where does the enemy?  What naval waters do I control, which ones are contested?  What naval waters do I have the upper hand and where does the enemy?  Combine that with the challenge of fighting in multiple theaters at once and it all becomes overwhelming.

146357226.review:
Huge fan of Stellaris, had this recommended to me by a friend. The gameplay is similar, but the army is a lot more complicated. Like most Paradox games, this one takes a bunch of tries to figure out what you're doing, but overall I found it pretty manageable to get into once I stopped beating my head against a wall. 

What gets this game a negative from me is how much of the non-combat interactions are purely RNG. The reliance on chance to determine events means that things that logically should happen over the course of interactions with the AI may just never happen.

In two separate games, I pushed my neighbors to 65-70% ideological similarity to me and destabilized their governments to prompt a peaceful change of power. Despite maintaining 20-30% stability in the nations for more than a year, improving my relations with them, and having a significantly larger army/more infrastructure, neither flipped to my ideology. Instead, after about 18 months, one of the two flipped to a democratic majority (I assume some focus that boosted the faction), reducing my ideology by 30% in the process. 

To me, this game feels like Paradox got so caught up in making sure that players couldn't find easy and predictable ways to win that they completely removed any predictability from everything but combat. I've read that this isn't really the paradox game for diplomacy, but being pushed into fights by stubborn/random AI is unbelievably frustrating when I'm doing literally everything I can do to make them like/cooperate with me.

147419432.review:
Too complicated...

Note that I said "complicated", not "difficult".

In the early HoI4 builds, you could actually micromanage your nation without effort. Most of the stuff you did happened using the base game mechanics, and the latter were similar to what you had in HoI2. "Decisions" gave the game flavor and allowed for historical or ahistorical outcomes that couldn't be replicated by the base game mechanics alone.

In the current state of the game, decisions NO LONGER COMPLEMENT base game mechanics. They ARE a major game mechanic.

As such, you have TOO many of them. Focus tree decisions for building industry. Focus tree decisions for building infrastructure. Focus tree decisions for diplomacy.

Do not get me wrong. Having extensive focus trees can be great for the AI. But they cause me, the player, to suffocate.

23486577.review:
Edit: I first wrote this review several years ago and it's continued to receive likes and awards but was no longer relevant to the current state of the game, so I've decided to update it to reflect how I feel about the game now (Autumn 2021).

The issues I identified originally:

1: Germany is far too weak: This was fixed as I suggested by increasing production and adding crippling morale penalties to France

2: The British Empire is hyper aggressive: This was also fixed by reducing Britain's production and adding penalties making it hard to militarise the UK before the war actually starts.

3: Air casualties are far too high: This has also been fixed and air casulaties are reasonable. Major nations should no longer be out of fighters in the first month of the war.

4: Balancing certain air missions seems to be off: This was largely fixed. I still think Strategic bombing is a waste of time - mostly because the upfront investment to even build strategic bombers is just too high (see my new criticisms below)

5: Naval stacking doesn't seem to cause a penalty: Penalties have been added, so it no longer makes sense to just have one doomfleet.

I stand by my original claim that these are balancing tweaks and they have been largely tweaked away.

I also identified that there was a problem with fuel not being treated as a consumable resource which removed many of the historical pressures and reasons why nations acted like they did. This was fixed by Paradox some time ago, and fuel is now a very real pressure for Germany and Japan as it was historically.

However, there are now some new and slightly annoying balancing tweaks which I'd like to see addressed:

1. There are too many research options and too few slots/research takes too long. As it currently is, they've added so many things to research, many of them very cool, but there's no way to research them without totally hobbling yourself. For example, historically the UK managed to keep on top of basically all sorts of aircraft designs, ship designs, medium, light and heavy tank designs (plus associated TDs), infantry equipment designs, and various secret projects like RADAR and nuclear weapons. In game there just isn't the capacity to do this. You're likely going  to likely only research one type of tank (light then medium), one type of bomber (probably CAS or TAC), and probably fall behind on capital ships, due to the lack of research capacity. I have so far never bothered to even research scout planes because it feels like the research slot is always better deployed on something (anything) else. I think there should be some more ways to specialise national research. In HOI 3 this was through the research organisations giving particular bonuses. I think this should make a comeback via the 'concerns' in the politics menu - these already offer some bonuses in some cases but I think this should be extended greatly. I also think they should be easier to appoint earlier so that you can specialise earlier. Perhaps appointing your first concern for an area should be cheaper, but changing later more expensive.

2. Similarly, production even for very industrial nations like Germany doesn't feel strong enough to keep up with all the options. This obviously needs to be a limiting factor as it was historically but usually it just doesn't make sense to build any of the more esoteric units, e.g. swimming tanks, or self-propelled rocket artillery, because throwing factories at infantry equipment is *so much more important*. This leads to most nations playing the same - build infantry equipment, support equipment, trucks, artillery, fighters, CAS, medium tanks. Deviation is a great way to run out of equipment and lose the war. Obviously these pressures are key to how the game works, but it feels like there needs to be some sort of system to encourage diversification. Perhaps for example, factories could be more nuanced than 'military' or 'civilian' - a light arms factory is very different from a car factory. Perhaps a car factory could be re-purposed to produce vehicles but not guns.


I still think the mechanics are the best they've ever been. In comparison to HOI3 it's a far more streamlined experience, and managing your forces is so much easier. No more screwing around with endless levels of military hierarchy and hundreds and hundreds of generals who all become interchangeable anyway. Here there are only four levels - division, army, group and theatre - and you assign generals to armies and Field Marshalls to Groups. Similarly, while in HOI3 manageing your airforce was such an enormous pain, and the effects of air superiority so minor that it basically was not worth it, here air power is much much easier to control and project and will be central to your overall strategy. Navies have also had a makeover although I haven't yet played any major sea power so won't comment on their effectiveness.

There's also an entirely new production system which is 1: vastly superior and 2: makes a lot more sense. Whereas previously you "built" divisions, here each division requires particular equipment dictated by its design as well as time to train. In terms of equipment they need guns, supplies, artillery, anti-tank guns, and particular vehicles, all of which need to be produced by your production lines which you set up and control. The way that this equipment is then handled means that upgrades are simulated much more realistically. In HOI3 a brigade used the previous technology until 100% upgraded, and this made no sense: your Panzer 3s had little percentage meters which when filled magiced them into Panzer 4s, your infantry used 1936 weapons until *every single 1938 weapon they needed arrived* then switched. Here divisions use whatever they can get from the stockpile, meaning that your divisions take delivery of new equipment as it arrives and replace losses with whatever you have available. So for example if your tank production doesn't keep up, your panzer divisions will fill the missing slots with whatever old crap was sitting in the depot. Oh and about that time to train - if the Motherland needs divisions comrade, you can simply hand them a rifle from the pile and point them at the Germans...

Finally the AI is better in several respects. For example it is far better at naval invasions now (in fact, it's a bit too keen on them) so Britain doesn't sit around uselessly unless player controlled. It's also much better at manageing forces and maintaining a front line so it's not so prone to huge encirclements. It seems to handle terrain better too, and pick good places to push and excellent defensive positions (which can grind things to a halt). It also seems to be a lot less predictable and capable of pulling off some rather complicated plans - I saw, for example, Japan launch an enormous pincer maneuvre on China, invading from both the North and South and cutting the country in half, trapping most of the Chinese forces out of supply. It's had some problems in the past with over-committing on low priority fronts but it seems to have improved in this regard in recent patches.

Overall this is, in my opinion, *the* WW2 grand strategy game. I keep coming back to it and lose hours every time I do.

48714974.review:
This game vs. HOI3:
---------------------

Advantages:

1.) The production system is more interesting and engaging, and far more balanced than the old IC system of HOI3. 
2.) The unit creation system is far more in depth and interesting, featuring many different brigade types and support companies, allowing you to change your divisions however you would like. 
3.) This game is far more stable than HOI3.
4.) This game is updated regularly and has bugfixes regularly too, with content being added free along with every DLC. 
5.) The modding community of HOI4 is far larger with excellent mods such as Kaiserreich, Millenium Dawn, Red World, and Endseig.
6.) HOI4 muliplayer is actually playable without making you want to shoot yourself.
7.) China is no longer something Japan can take within 2 months.
8.) An actual peace conference system and ideologies that actually impact the game.
9.) Far easier to get into than HOI3.
10.) Less railroading and the AI wont spaz if you do something ahistorical.
11.) Planes are no longer as cancer as they used to be.
12.) Far less micromanagement if you choose not to want to micro.
13.) A better tutorial (still not a great one though.)


Disadvantages:

1.) The research system is bare bones in comparison to HOI3.
2.) The War in the Pacific is basically nonexistant and naval warfare is awful (to be improved with next patch, being released eventually:tm:)
3.) People dont really join the war in HOI4 unless theyre directly attacked, making continents like South America completely useless due to the fact that none of the countries there ever do anything but still build up their military, contributing lag.
4.) Due to the game's engine, it can only use a single one of your processing cores, meaning regardless of your computer quality the game will run kinda slowly.
5.) Speaking of slowly, the game is poorly optimized and frame loss is extremely common, especially 1942 onwards, when majors can have upwards of 300+ divisions. 
6.) The AI is often braindead, doing hilariously incompetent things such as charging endlessly into your lines, removing all its troops from your front, leaving major areas completely undefended, and completely ignoring the aerial aspect of the war.
7.) Specific AI are even more braindead than the rest, specifically island nations, or nations that otherwise need to use navies and airforces more. Yes, the Japanese, American, and British AI are some of the worst in the game. In a WW2 game. 
8.) Your allies are completely useless and often you will find yourself doing all the fighting yourself, or even being hindered by your own allies. Playing as Germany the Italians likely wont place a single division in North Africa. In D-Day, you will either be the only one contributing anything or your allies will contribute so much that the supply is ruined and your troops all die of attrition. As the USSR you will recieve 0 lend lease, and as China you will get absolutely no support from the west. 
9.) HOI3 is a lot cheaper than HOI4


Other things which I feel are worth mentioning but arent really advantages or disadvantages:

1.) HOI4 contains a lot more alt-history options, which while not for everyone, are fun to try out. 
2.) The focus-tree system is something completely different from anything in HOI3.
3.) The game has a less in-depth OOB(Order of Battle), which while to some people is nice because theyre bad with OOB, others dislike. Specifically this game lacks corps. 
4.) The battle-planning system of HOI4, while easier to use than the one in HOI3, is still flawwed. In HOI3 it did absolutely nothing, but in this game it is a core part of playing. Unless you want to mircomanage every single division, like you did in HOI3, you will use this system. 
5.) While simpler, the game still possesses a learning curve.

------------------------

Overall: 

HOI4 is a far less grounded and historical experience than HOI3. Is this a good or bad thing? That depends on your perspective. HOI4 obviously has significant advantages over HOI3 in certain areas but many consider HOI3 to be an overall better game. Personally I recommend HOI3 if you want a more micro-intensive, historical experience, and HOI4 if you want to just sit back and relax for a couple hours murdering millions of people. 

Personally I would suggest either game, but thats just me.

This is a bit hard to reccomend. The AI is a bit dumb, and will regularly leave it's front undefended, and when fighting alongside you, will never move thier units into a coherent fighting force. I played France in my own alliance, and after wiping Germany and the rest of the Axis, we warred with the Soviets, with America joining in. America kept most of it's units off the front, forcing my military to bear the brunt of a full soviet assault, which was very taxing on my manpower. It's fun designing units, and devising strategies, and picking the right time to strike, and the right things to build at the right time. 

That aside, Paradox has been very poor in it's decision making for the DLCs. The most recent, death or dishonor, honestly should've been a patch. They do the same thing for Stellaris, where MAJOR GAME CHANGES are kept behind a paywall. But, if Paradox pulls it's head out of it's butt, like many companies are doing slowly, than this may be one of the best grand strategy games ever. So I do recomend.  Just expect to pay about $70 for the final product.

EDIT: The cornflakes free update has fixed many of the AI problems that where present. it still isn't the best at making intelligent decisions (such as communist China going to war with China AND Manchukuo after Japan had a civil war and went democratic), but it can at least wage war now. Front lines shift realistically, units get cut off, and will attempt to re-establish supply lines, and when backed into a corner, the AI won't just stuff 100 undersupllied units into 5 districts to try to keep it.

42462187.review:
Well, after spending enough time with this game I think I'm finally able to review it. If you're one of those people quickly scrolling through to get a general idea of wether or not you should buy, I reccomend it. If you want a more informed opinion, feel free to keep reading. 

OVERVIEW:
Hearts of Iron IV is a "Grand Stratagy" game set during the turmoil of the 1930's/40's and the Second World War. You can command any nation around the world and lead it on to the world stage and on to glory. You must choose wether or not to begin playing in either 1936 or 1939. The former allows for a more custom setup and is better for playing small nations. If you're trigger-happy and eager to send millions of young men to their deaths, you can choose 1939, grab your gun and leap into the fray. No matter which country you command, you can customize it to your liking. You can change their ideology, strengthen their economy, and lead them to dominate the earth! You can create a fascist Finland, a communist Australia, or a democratic Venezuela (good luck with that one). You also have complete control over all armed forces of your nation, and you can practically do anything with them! If you wish to send hordes of unarmed men at the enemy's machine guns and trenches, you go right ahead. Now this game has many in's and out's that I could go on for hours about, but most of those things are easy to understand, and the internet exists for a reason! However, I will offer some advice to new players. 

ADVICE TO THE PLEBS: 
Good first-playthrough countries are Italy, Germany, the Soviet Union, or the United States. 

Only make trade deals if you have no other choice-don't give away all your factories!

Remember to change the conscription laws when you are at war! You can do this by clickling on your country's flag and clicking on the conscription icon. "Quantity has a quality of it's own" -Joseph Stalin

Keep your fleets in port until you want to launch a naval invasion, then unleash them on the part of the sea you need to control in order to send transports through. By then your fleets should be large enough to hold off the enemy. This is especially true for Germany. The moment you send your fleet out, the entire Royal Navy will drop by for target practice and sink all of your ships. I know because it's happened to me. 

Convoy Raiding is, admittedly, a joke in this game and it's not worth losing all of your submarines for. 

Always make frontlines with your armies. Don't just deploy your men willy nilly, otherwise the enemy will break through quickly.

If you're the impatient sort and playing with a country that has a lot of resources, I reccomend the Mobile Warfare doctrine with some lovely Medium Tank divisions. Those guys can always win a war quickly. 

Don't try to research everything.

If you plan on conquering a lot, research Military Police early on and assign them with cavalry, and put them on conquered states. You'll thank me later.

Now then, let's go over the overall pros and cons!
PROS and CONS
+Endless replayability 
+Few restrictions on gameplay
+Land Warfare is (for the most part) simple enough to understand
+Division customization allows for custom armies
+The music is excellent
+Lots of opportunity for customization and creativity
+Fantastic modding community- Mods add hundreds more hours of playtime
+Mods and add pretty much anything you want into the game (Unit models, Music, ect.)
+You don't need any DLC for most mods, unlike other Paradox games
+Multiplayer is a good time

-Not enough natural resources, really annoying
-Naval combat is very hard to understand unless you're playing as Great Britain
-Naval combat is missing historical elements. It'll probably be fixed with a DLC, knowing Paradox
-The AI isn't perfect and can make some horrific strategic moves
-No coordination with ally AI on military stratagey
-Aerial combat, in it's current state, is simply throwing planes into the sky and seeing which side has more of them
-The treaty system has a lot of issues, but these can be fixed by the Player-Led Treaty mod and the State-Transfer mod

BEST PRO: The glorious feeling you get when you crush your enemies! Leading a country through WWII to victory is very satisfying and I believe the game has accomplished it's goal of bringing the grand strategy of the war into the player's control.
WORST CON: During the late game, most countries will have created hundreds of divisions. While this doesn't affect me that badly, it can cause a tremendous amount of lag and I've heard from several people that it has made their late-game saves unplayable. Paradox (or some modder) needs to implement a system in which the AI lessens the amount of divisions it has when it is at peace.

OVERALL RATING: 8/10 
Though the game has it's faults and some aspects of it are difficult to understand, Hearts of Iron IV allows the player a thoroughly enjoyable experience for those who enjoy both History and Grand Stratagy. Now if you don't mind, I must return to my command tank and finish the conquest of Europe. Soon the entire world will tremble before the might of the fatherland! Achtung, Panzer!

70909648.review:
So. 1,000 hours of Hearts of Iron 4 later, and I still honestly don't know how I feel about this game. It's... an interesting experience, to say the least, there's certainly not many other games like it that I know of. 

You want a TL:DR at the start? Sure, I can recommend this game, but that's with a very bit asterisk next to it.

To start with the pros, its definitely a very enjoyable game in the early stages of any match; the feeling of evaluating what you have to work with and then building up slowly in power, or starting off at a breakneck speed for some countries is spot on. The graphics, though a little rough at points are really great overall and do a wonderful job of conveying everything to the player. The menus, controls and UI, though complicated at first, are quick and efficient once you get them down. The sheer amount of variety in terms of playable countries (That is literally all of them) is also a big plus. Even though countries like Bhutan, Tibet or Nicaragua are dull as dirt once the novelty wears off, the sheer fact that the option is there is definitely commendable, as is the amount of branching and varied paths for each of the countries with a focus tree.

With that said, however, the game has plenty of flaws, foremost among them being the AI. It will either be the most formidable and downright unfairly impossible opponent to ever walk the Earth, or it will put up the resistance of a wet packet of spaghetti, and very rarely any level between that. Italy and the USSR are sorely lacking their updated focus trees, and whilst they are likely to come in a future DLC that doesn't change how dull they are to play currently unless you specifically want to play as Mussolini or Stalin, and whilst Italy tends to scrape by because of it's annoying navy and colonies, the USSR is almost a pushover at this point. Stalin can't ever seem to hold his territory and only ever seems to succeed when he's beating up countries twenty times smaller than his, and even then that's not a 100% for him. This makes trying to play any historical game a nightmare because he Nazi's, or just Germany in general are so absurdly powerful that they'll just steamroll the USSR without allowing for a truly historical game. Speaking of Germany, the fact that I never really set the AI to the fascist path anymore speaks to how annoyingly powerful they are; it's genuinely a disheartening time trying to have fun only to get run over by Germany's 600 suspiciously perfectly equipped divisions and 5,000 fighter planes (Not exaggerated numbers by any stretch) and then to end WW2 in an endless face-off between them and the Brits because the devs never programmed the German AI to know what a naval invasion is. The point of this is that often the AI becomes a roadblock to the player's fun, rather than a challenging opponent; Your allies sometimes become more of a pain than an comrade as their priorities are so messed up and incomprehensible that often you can find yourself thanking the random horde of Greek or Swedish troops holding your borders whilst wondering why the British abandoned Africa to the Italians, or the French leaving twelve guys, a box of wine and a cheese wheel to fend off seventy Italian divisions barrelling across the Alpes. 

And then there's the DLC. Overall, have they greatly improved the gameplay and made things more immersive? Definitely. Should these parts of the game have been cut out and then sold back to you for an added fee? Hell no. Sure, one can argue that these were aspects the devs needed extra time to implement, or that they only thought of them later on, but that does not justify that in order to play Hearts of Iron 4 in any meaningful capacity beyond a basic WW2 sim, which by this point is one of the worse aspects of the game, you need to essentially pay for the game all over again and then some, which is just not acceptable to me.


So yes, overall I can say I can recommend this game for those who want a political or military wargame set in the 1930s and 40s, and who want to try interesting, unique or just plain silly alternate history options. But be very aware that the game only has so much content before you need to start relying on messing around with friends to keep it interesting, and make sure you're willing to buy at least some of the DLC, because otherwise you're not going to have much of a game to play.
Overall, a fairly solid 7/10 from me; a game whose pros are that it offers a unique wargaming situation in one of the most turbulent times in recent history, with plenty of interesting gameplay options and little intricacies even I'm still discovering, but whose cons are a predatory DLC system scooping out gameplay aspects to be sold back to the player and an AI who reaches Rome Total War 2 levels of bad more often than I would like to admit.
A true TL:DR? A WW2 sim that can be fun, but play only if you have no regard for your time or your wallet.

It is 1938 and the Munich Conference is in to discuss theSudeten crisis. France and the United Kingdom came to decide the fate of little Czechoslovakia's northern front, the Sudetenland. Both of these powerful nations, France and the U.K. decided to fall in to the German Reich's demands for the land, effectively giving it to them. But when the German soldiers went to their "newly aquired lands" they saw forts, bunkers and all sorts of fortifications along the border, with Czechoslovakian flags held high. See, the Czechs had a fear of this crisis since 1936, and they acted on it. They build great land forts, built the army, worked on moving to a full war economy and mass produced weapons. The Czechs were ready to defend their rightful home. 2 months will pass and the German Reich will demand that Czechoslovakia surrender the land or there will be war... The Czech president sent a message to the German aggressors, "Come and take it", at that moment, In 1938, the German Reich decalred war on the Czechs. No help from the U.K. or France made the situation look dire, but the brave Czechs had a plan, they reformed the "Little Enente" of Yugoslovia and Romania. Hungary, bordering the east of Czechslovakia would go onto join the Axis, and try to invade Slovakia, but Romanian troops will crush the Hungarian menace, and absorb their lands. Its now 1939 and Italy has not decided to enter the war, and Romanian and Yugoslavian troops occupied by fighting to defend Yugoslavia from German invasions, was unable to help the Czechs against Germany, Czechoslovakia stood alone. They saw the German army, the Panzers, the Luffwaffe, and decided that they must hold the line. Winter, 1939 German troops are suffering heavy from attrition, the Czechs have been prepared for winter and have plenty of equipment to hold, then, on December 17, 1939, the Field Marshall of the Czecholslovakian Army ordered a push to attack the encamped Germany attackers. The Czechs raided out of their bunkers and attacked the unprepared Germany army. The Germans were rapidly pushed back, Almost no rest for the retreating German army made them weak. January 12, 1940 -- The capital of the former nation Austria, Vienna, has been taken by Czech forces, the same will be with Nuremberg, Munich. March 11, All of former Austria has been taken by Czech forces, and the entire southern half of Germany has been taken. March 13, The Soviet Union will inavde Poland, and begin to justify war against the Czechoslovakian goverment. In March 27, 1940, the capital of the German Reich, Berlin, will fall to Czech forces, Germany is contemplating surrender. A day later, March 28th, Italy will decide it cannont stand idely by while their ally is being demolished, they declare war on Czechoslovakia. Italy will launch a full invasion on Yugoslavia, in April, Yugoslavia will capitulate to the Italians. Every bit of Germany has been taken except the city of Hamburg, the last bastion of the Nazi goverement. In September of 1940, the German Reich will capitulate to Czech troops. Italy stands alone against the Czech might, A massive army pushed down the Italian pennisula and in December of 1940, Rome will fall. In Early 1941, Italy will surrender to Czech forces, and will be left with control only over Sicily and Sardina, effectively kicked off mainland Europe. In March of 1941, Japan will enter the war and attempt to restore the GErman Reich, their invasion will be stopped. In May, 1941, Japan will give up on the war and ask for peace. The Allies are fighting against Comintern forces while the Czechs consolidate their newly aquired land of Germany, Austria and Italy... and remember the day that when their freedom was in danger, they fought, fought valiantly for it, and won.

The course of human history was changed that day, WW2 never occured, America and the Allies will fight and destory the Soviet Union in late 1944, the Cold War will never happen, and Czechoslovakia will become one of the most powerful nations in the world. Czechmate.

15/15 Would change history again

36521095.review:
The newest addition to the Hearts of Iron series is the most user-friendly (almost as the Civilization 5) and war-mongering as always. Just like so many other Paradox global strategies, you take control of the one particular state (which can be as big as Soviet Union/USA or as small as Luxemburg). You're making calls with industry, technologies and infernal politics, preparing for the grand war, which is so close. And then you must fight. Even if you choose some state on the outskirts of the world, like New Zealand or Haiti - it doesn't mean you'll evade the global skirmish. You'll be bored all the way - but eventually, the war will come to you as well.

I have an ambivalent opinion of HoI 4 and don't recommend it as an instant buy. Maybe Paradox will patch some questionable features sometimes... But maybe they'll just make the next, better game. Or they'll make the next HoI even worse, who knows? Yeah, sure, it developed a lot in little details since the 1.0 up to 1.4 version, I can easily agree with that. But, some things, are not too right in the very basic concept.

The most noticeable pro point of the 4th volume (above the 3rd HoI) is an aeons more acceptable interface and tutorial. The game's mechanics are still very complicated, but, at least, you can learn it without your head boiling too hot. However, there is a catch: once you'll learn "the better way" for every country, it's really not fun to play it again. The limit of replayability is still quite high - but it's countable. It's good for game sellers, so they can sell the next almost-similar game faster (the Call-of-Duty syndrome). But it certainly lowers the overall score of the one particular game for me.

What is worse, while basically, every country has at least 3 different ways to go, Democratic, Socialistic or Fascist, it's obvious that for the most cases, the Fascist way benefits the player much more. "C'mon, game, make me a Fascist! Faster!" - that's a common phrase among Youtube letsplayers. Some may argue, like, would Paradox make it another way - the Axis would be loosing way too often. Maybe. But look at the achievements. There is one, "NewWorldOrder", make all the world brown, but why there aren't such trophies for Blue and Red sides? Well, it's not a secret that the dev's are favouring Hitler - maybe not as a person, but as a political figure... But, even in the 3rd Hearts of Iron, where Adolf get a cameo in so-called "tutorial", it wasn't so one-way oriented.

Turning fascist as a key strategy to win the war is only one minus point. The much more severe case is all diplomatics in general. First, there are political blocks. And if you're, say, choosing Allies, you can't then skip to the Comintern or Axis during the war. And even if both Allies and Comintern are fighting Axis together, like as in known history, they are still not counting as allies between each other. Next, even worse, is about running some of those blocks yourself. Example - an achievement for Mexico, to land onto Europe, either not allied with anybody, or having the alliance only with South America countries. For Mexico, it's crucial to make at least small alliance - without it, you can't open the 5th research slot, therefore, you'll be losing the tech race. So I made a fine alliance with Colombia, conquered the USA (for another Mexico achievement) and started preparations for the invasion on Europe. All goes well until Germany and Italy both lose. Then, all the small states, which were associated with Axis, suddenly landed in my faction, without even asking! Just because of some game rule, it can sometimes apply or disengage some countries in your alliance. And You - Don't. I understand it was made not to ruin some multiplayer games, but now it certainly ruins single-play.

Next, the wars. At first, they seem much clever than in the 2nd and 3rd HoI - you can issue your generals some master plan, and they will be pursuing it by themselves - which especially cool, if you have multiple wars or fronts simultaneously. But then you notice that every war where you move troops yourself proceeds much faster and better than leaving it to AI. So, no, the micromanagement is still a must, for almost every operation. You have to move your troops yourself, and you always need to observe all your territories, or enemies will make an invasion far in your safe zone and conquer your capital city, while your main forces will be very far away, like in Africa or India... AI battleplan logic, even based on the stats unknown to a player (like the size of fortifications, for the most obvious example) - still lose too many manpower in every war, every single battle, with constant zerg rushes and zeroed organization stat. Remember human waves cliche? Well, it's the most obvious tactic for the AI, not for Russia or China, but for every country.

More to it! By some strange logic, if your forces are attacking from the territory of another state, the game counts them as the forces of that state. Like if Soviets goes through neutral Poland straight to Berlin, the game greets brave Poles for Their success! And if you conquer some distant land like Australia, you can't be sure, that the game counts that victory to you. In my case, another (allied) nation landed in another part of that continent, haven't got at least one city - but was awarded as a whole winner when I took Canberra.

Or, another case, back to weird diplomacy. The civil war started in Norway, Sweden, and Afganistan. One side marked as Axis, other as Comintern, the game merged all civil wars together with some other conflicts, basically, the World War has started. I, as the Soviet Union, with help from Finland, took the northern parts of Norway and Sweden, and all was going well, I was so close to their capitals when Soviet Afganistan have lost its domestic war. Right away, the game makes some automatic treaty and counts all three civil wars as closed, and Axis forces as winners. All the northern parts of Sweden and Norway now belongs to Axis and all the local forces that were on the Soviet side, now our enemies. Just because the game says so. Yeah, very logical, very realistic.

I can proceed with examples, but they will take us too long. Aviation and artillery cases still far from perfect, and instead of fixing it, Paradox in ver. 1.4 killed the fleet strategies as well... Even the sound options menu is still far from perfect, as it counts some random and totally irrelevant background sounds like shooting and howling of planes on fly-by as "effect" and not "ambient". And if you don't want to hear all those stupid "wruum, bah-bah" all the way, but want to hear sounds when clicking buttons - sorry! It's the 1+1 type of deal! Take the good with the bad, or leave it be!

Just like that, there are too many sides of this really good and complex game, which don't feel alright. Let's finish there, with a quick summary. Is the game better than the 2nd or 3rd Hearts of Iron? With visuals and lower entry level, with the better aid of modders straight from the Steam Community - Yes, naturally.

You'll still need to learn many things there to operate successfully. But once you'll manage that learning curve (about 30-100 hours average) - you'll start to lose your interest, as it's all not that random, as with Civilization games, and not that logically and historically correct, as previous Paradox games. On the other hand, those questionable game decisions made multiplayer much more acceptable, in general gaming sense. As a solo player, I can't really agree with that turn of the tide. With all disadvantages from diplomacy and other game mechanics, I can't value it higher than 7/10. Buy it at your own risk. There are no such limitations as with previous games like you've might hear, "play it only if you're good enough with Europa Universalis" or so, but, if you're wasn't daydreaming on history and logic classes, the 4th HoI still leaving too much to wish for sweeten the taste.
